column1: Cagayan de Oro
column2: officially the City of Cagayan de Oro (Cebuano: Dakbayan sa Cagayan de Oro; Tagalog: Lungsod ng Cagayan de Oro)
column3: or simply referred to as CDO
column4: is a 1st class highly urbanized city in Northern Mindanao
column5: Philippines. It is the capital of the province of Misamis Oriental where it is geographically situated but governed administratively independent from it. According to the 2015 census
column7: 950 people. It also serves as the regional center and business hub of Northern Mindanao (Region X)
column8: and part of the growing Metropolitan Cagayan de Oro area
column9: which includes the city of El Salvador

column1: The City of Cagayan de Oro is located along the north central coast of Mindanao island facing Macajalar Bay and is bordered by the municipalities of Opol to the west
column3: and the provinces of Bukidnon and Lanao del Norte to the south of the city. According to the 2015 census
column4: the city has a population of 675
column6: making it the 10th most populous city in the Philippines. Cagayan de Oro is also famous for its white water rafting or kayaking adventures
column7: one of the tourism activities being promoted along the Cagayan de Oro River.

column1: == Etymology ==
The name Cagayan de Oro (lit. River of Gold) can be traced back to the arrival of the Spanish Augustinian Recollect friars in 1622
column3: was already known as "Cagayán". Early Spanish written documents in the 16th century already referred to the place as "Cagayán".

column1: The region of Northern Mindanao
column3: was granted as encomienda to a certain Don Juan Griego on January 25
column4: 1571. It was then former Vice President of the Philippines Emmanuel Peláez who appended de Oro to Cagayan.

column1: There are also other places in the Philippines with the Cagayan name; these include the province of Cagayan in northern Luzon
column2: the Cagayan Islands in the northern Sulu Sea
column3: and the island of Mapun in Tawi-Tawi (formerly known as Cagayan de Sulu).

column1: == History ==
=== Classical period ===
The Cagayan de Oro area was continuously inhabited by Late Neolithic to Iron Age Austronesian cultures. The oldest human remains discovered was from the Huluga Caves
column2: once used as a burial place by the natives. A skullcap sent to the Scripps Institution of Oceanography in 1977 was dated to be from between 350-377 AD. The caves have yielded numerous artifacts
column3: but most areas have been badly damaged by guano collectors and amateur treasure hunters. Associated with the cave is the Huluga Open Site
column4: believed to be the site of the primary pre-colonial settlement in the region identified as  "Himologan" by the first Spanish missionaries. The site is located about eight kilometers from present-day Cagayan de Oro. The discovery of a grave site in 2009 uncovered remains of Song Dynasty (960-1279 AD) celadon ware and Sukhothai period (1238–1347 AD) Sangkhalok ceramic ware
column5: in addition to body ornaments and stone tools. It indicates that the region was part of the ancient maritime trading network of Southeast Asia. Skulls recovered from the sites show that native Kagay-anons practiced artificial cranial deformation since childhood as a mark of social status
column6: similar to skulls from archeological sites in neighboring Butuan.The Huluga Open Site was damaged extensively in 2001 to give way to a bridge project by the local administration. It was the source of controversy when a team from the University of the Philippines-Archaeological Studies Program dismissed the archeological importance of the site by declaring it as a "camp-like area" and not a settlement and thus not worthy of heritage protection under the laws. It was alleged by local conservationists that the UP-ASP team were influenced by the local government so the bridge project could continue. The site is still not protected and continue to be quarried
column7: despite protests by local historians and archeologists.

column1: === Colonial period ===
==== Spanish period ====
The Himologan settlement was still occupied by the time the Europeans made contact. In 1622
column2: two Spanish Augustinian Recollect missionaries reached the settlement and described it as being inhabited by a mixed stock descended from highlander Bukidnon Lumad and sea-faring Visayans ("Dumagat"). They described the men of the settlement as being tattooed like other Visayans and the women as being ornamented with intricate jewelry
column3: some of which were golden. They also identified them as animists
column4: practicing traditional anitism
column5: though they paid tribute to Muhammad Kudarat
column6: the sultan of the Islamized Sultanate of Maguindanao to the south.In 1626
column7: Fray Agustín de San Pedro persuaded the chief of Himologan
column8: Datu Salangsang
column9: to transfer his settlement down the Cagayan River
column10: to the present-day Gaston Park. De San Pedro later fortified the new settlement against Sultan Kudarat's raiders.

column2: Spanish dominance was felt in Cagayan de Oro. When Misamis gained the status of province in 1818
column3: one of its four districts was the Partidos de Cagayan. In 1871
column4: the "Partidos" became a town and was made a permanent capital of Misamis.

column1: On February 27
column3: Governor-General Carlos María de La Torre issued a decree declaring Cagayan the permanent capital of Segundo Distrito de Misamis. During this era
column4: the name of the town was known as Cagayan de Misamis.

column2: the town became a seat of the Spanish government in Mindanao for the provinces of Misamis Oriental
column3: Misamis Occidental
column4: Bukidnon and Lanao del Norte.

column1: On January 10
column3: Cagayan de Misamis joined the government of Emilio Aguinaldo and celebrated its independence from Spain. It was the second time the Aguinaldo government was declared and the new Philippine flag raised on the Mindanao island. By virtue of the 1898 Treaty of Paris
column4: Spain ceded the Philippines to the United States; this caused friction and resulted in the Philippine-American War.

column1: ==== American period ====
On March 31
column3: Americans occupied the town of Cagayan de Misamis and on April 7
column5: a battle erupted in the town center led by General Nicolas Capistrano and Filipino resistance fighters. This would later become known as the Battle of Cagayan de Misamis. The Americans won the war
column7: gave the Philippines its independence on July 4
column8: 1946. The war years in Cagayan de Oro were prompted by the presence of the Americans in 1898. The Americans were initially and successfully repulsed by the Kagay-anons forces led by Mayor Don Apolinar Vélez at the historic Battle of Makahambus on June 4

column1: After the troubled years
column2: peace finally brought back the economic activities to normality under the guidance of the United States. Consequently
column3: from a purely farming-fishing area
column4: Cagayan de Oro emerged into a booming commerce and trade center.

column1: ==== Japanese period and second American period ====
May 3
column3: American and Philippine forces fought heroically against invading Japanese forces from Panay. Unable to resist the overwhelming and the better supplied Japanese
column4: the allied forces retreated to more defensive positions outside the city. The Japanese burned most of the city and took up residence at Ateneo De Cagayan university
column5: now Xavier university and used the ferry crossing near San Agustin Church. The Carmen bridge did not exist at that time.

column1: The Japanese army implemented a scorch-earth policy. Filipino and American guerrilla forces fought back during this occupation and American planes bombed both the university and San Agustin church on October 10
column2: 1944. The Japanese were never able to successfully move outside the city for any length of time due to the constant pressure and attacks from the Philippine resistant movement. Combined American and Free Philippine forces landed in Cagayan de Oro on May 10
column4: three years and 7 days after the Japanese occupation.

column1: During this period the Japanese committed many atrocities against the local population of Cagayan de Oro
column2: as they did throughout the Philippines. Colonel Fumio Suzuki and two hundred of his men escaped capture during the liberation of the city and withdrew into the mountainous jungle. They were caught two years later; only 38 survived by cannibalizing the Higaonon tribal people. At least 70 people were eaten.

column1: A Cagayanon
column3: was a member of an espionage team working for the return of Gen. Douglas MacArthur to the Philippines. Later
column4: he became part of a Manila spy network. He was captured
column5: tortured and decapitated by the Japanese.

column1: === Postwar era ===

column2: the barrios of El Salvador and Molugan with their sitios known as Sala
column3: Sambulawan
column4: Sinaloc
column7: Kalabaylabay and Hinigdaan were separated from Cagayan de Oro to form the town of El Salvador.In 1950
column8: the barrios of Opol
column10: and lower Iponan (now Barangay Barra) were separated from Cagayan de Oro to form the town of Opol.On June 15
column12: President Elpidio Quirino signed Republic Act No. 521
column13: which granted the status of a chartered city to the Municipality of Cagayan de Misamis. This was made possible through the efforts of then Cagayan de Oro Congressman Emmanuel Pelaez.

column1: === Martial law era ===
During the martial law era
column2: Cagayan de Oro was not spared from military bombings and the usage of brutal mechanisms against dissenters of the Marcos regime. By the time martial law ended
column3: more than a thousand people from the city had been tortured
column4: raped

column1: Cagayan de Oro did not take these violations lightly
column2: and the city came to have a reputation as one of the centers of political opposition in the Philippines.Cagayan de Oro was declared a highly urbanized city by the Ministry of Local Government on November 22
column4: the city participated in the People Power Revolution through rallies in the streets of the city. When the revolution succeeded and ousted Marcos from power in Manila
column5: the city was among those who supported the installation of Corazon Aquino as president.

column1: === Recent history ===

column2: the National Museum of the Philippines recognized the archaeological value of Huluga when it gave the Open Site and caves separate accession numbers. In 1999
column3: however
column4: mayor Vicente Y. Emano conceived the plan to bulldoze Huluga to give way to a road-and-bridge project. The project was stopped in 2001
column5: but was eventually continued in 2002. The construction destroyed at least 60% of the archaeological site's open area
column6: where the majority of artifacts can be found. Protests against the heritage destruction was made by cultural experts
column7: but nothing happened with their plea. In 2003
column8: the Heritage Conservation Advocates (HCA) went to the open area of Huluga for a scientific surface investigation and managed to find earthenware
column13: and a whale harpoon similar to those being used in Lomblen Island
column14: Indonesia. The newly discovered artifacts proved that there are still many artifacts that can be found in the area. This caused the HCA to file a case against Emano and the contractor UKC Builders
column15: before the Environmental Management Bureau (EMB). However
column16: the construction continued and was inaugurated in September 2003 by Emano. A day later
column17: president Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo made a speech in UNESCO about her administration's gains in cultural conservation. In January 2004
column18: the city council enacted an ordinance that authorized Emano to sign a contract with the Archaeological Studies Program (ASP) of the University of the Philippines to do salvage archaeology in Huluga and vicinities. The program did not make cooperitve linkages with existing archeological programs from Xavier University. The ASP declared that the site was an ancient camp
column20: due to their findings in the destroyed archaeological site. The report did not consider the findings of Xavier University. The issue later climbed into the Philippine Senate
column21: where Loren Legarda issued a resolution for investigation of the matter
column22: but the investigation was never approved by the other members of the Senate. The artifacts found in the Huluga Caves and its destroyed open site from 1992 to 2003 are housed in Xavier University
column24: and the University of the Philippines.

column1: === Notable calamities ===
On the evening of December 16–17
column3: Tropical Storm Sendong (international name Washi) caused widespread flash flooding in Northern Mindanao. In Cagayan de Oro
column4: hundreds living near the banks of the Cagayan de Oro River were killed

column1: Officials said that despite government warning
column2: some people did not evacuate. Five people were killed in a landslide
column3: while others died in the flash floods which occurred overnight
column4: following 10 hours of rain
column5: compounded by overflowing rivers and tributaries. Most of the victims had been sleeping.

column1: In some areas
column2: up to 20 centimeters of rain fell in 24 hours. More than 2
column3: 000 were rescued
column4: according to the Armed Forces of the Philippines (AFP)
column6: 000 people were staying in 10 evacuation centers in Cagayan de Oro. Officials were also investigating reports that an entire village was swept away. The confirmed death toll from the disaster is 1
column8: Cagayan de Oro
column9: along with other parts of Visayas and Mindanao
column10: was impacted by a combination of a low-pressure area and the tail-end of a cold front. The heavy rain inundated many streets
column11: stranding many commuters. At the University of Science and Technology of Southern Philippines (USTP)
column13: 000 students were trapped as most of their campus was flooded. The students were forced to climb to the upper floors of the school's buildings and wait until rescue arrived. The city's shopping malls on Claro M. Recto Avenue were also severely affected
column14: with Limketkai Center completely inundated by the floodwaters. A basement parking area of a mall at the corner of Corrales St. was covered with water
column15: while another one near Bitan-ag Creek was flooded as well
column16: even though the area was elevated.On December 21
column18: Typhoon Vinta (international name Tembin) impacted most of Mindanao. It made its landfall in the Davao Region. Three bridges were closed due to rising water levels in Cagayan de Oro
column20: 719 individuals were forced to evacuate. Roughly 30
column21: 000 people were either stranded in ports or stayed in evacuation centers while 22
column22: 000 people moved to higher grounds due to heavy flooding.

column1: == Geography ==
Cagayan de Oro is located along the north central coast of Mindanao
column2: the second-largest island in the Philippine archipelago.

column1: The southern part of the city is bordered by the provinces of Bukidnon and Lanao del Norte. The municipality of Opol borders the city on the west and Tagoloan
column2: Misamis Oriental to the east. To the north lies Macajalar Bay facing the Bohol Sea.

column1: Its total land area is 488.86 km² representing 13.9 percent of the entire Misamis Oriental province. It includes 25 kilometers of coastline and a harbor
column2: Macajalar Bay. 44.7 percent of Cagayan de Oro is classified as agricultural land
column3: while 38.4 percent is classified as open spaces.The city is frequently categorized and referenced according to geographic factors: the 1st District (west of the Cagayan River) consisting of 24 barangays which are mostly suburban
column4: and the 2nd District (east of the river)
column6: including city proper barangays numbering from 1-40.

column1: === Climate ===
Under the Köppen climate classification system
column2: Cagayan de Oro has a tropical climate with an annual average temperature of 28 °C. In June 1998
column3: the city recorded its highest temperature to date of 39 °C.

column1: Cagayan de Oro does not receive an even amount of rainfall throughout the year. The driest months are March and April while August and September are the wettest months. The rainy or wet season lasts from June until November with the relatively drier seasons lasting from December until May. The city lies outside the typhoon belt but is affected by the Inter-Tropical Convergence Zone.
== Demographics ==
As of the 2015 census
column2: the city has a population of 675
column4: making it the 10th most populous city in the Philippines and 3rd most populous in Mindanao after Zamboanga City. About 44 percent of the household population in Cagayan de Oro classified themselves as ethnically mixed people
column7: while 28.07 percent as other ethnic groups. (2000 Census).

column1: === Religion ===
==== Roman Catholicism ====
Roman Catholicism is the city's dominant religion
column2: represented by almost 70 percent of the population. It is administered by the Archdiocese of Cagayan de Oro
column3: which comprises of the three civil provinces of Misamis Oriental
column4: Bukidnon
column6: and the entire Caraga region. It is a metropolitan seat on the island of Mindanao.

column1: The current archbishop in Cagayan de Oro is the Most Reverend José Araneta Cabantan
column3: who was installed on August 28
column4: 2020. His seat is located at the Saint Augustine Metropolitan Cathedral.

column1: Recently
column2: the Basilica of the Black Nazarene in Quiapo Church decided to move the replica statue of the Black Nazarene to Jesus Nazareno Parish Church in Cagayan de Oro along Claro M. Recto Avenue
column3: so that the Black Nazarene devotees from Mindanao do not have to travel to Quiapo in Manila for their annual pilgrimage.

column1: ==== Protestant and Evangelical Christianity ====
Protestant missionary activity in the city started in 1916
column2: although have grown in numbers in the recent decades. One of the known Protestant groups in the city is Pentecostalism
column3: which dramatically increased with 2.8 percent of the total population. About 20 churches have settled in the metropolitan area. Celebration International Church has one of the highest member attendances with a record of 735 members.

column1: In addition
column2: three main Pentecostal mother churches are situated in the suburban area and few in the metropolitan areas. Also
column3: Adventists
column4: Mormons
column5: and Methodists have also grown in numbers within the suburban areas.

column1: Other Christian churches include the Iglesia ni Cristo
column3: the United Church of Christ in the Philippines
column4: Christ's Commission Fellowship

column1: Islam is practiced mainly by Maranao settlers and the Balik Islam (reverts). Its population comprises of immigrants from nearby Iligan and Marawi

column4: and study. It has increased since the Marawi siege that started on May 23

column2: located in the corner of Aguinaldo and Domingo Velez streets
column3: is the oldest mosque in the city

column7: which also includes a madrasa and seminar building.

column1: ==== Other religions ====
Buddhism and Taoism are practiced by majority of local Chinese. Some are even members of the local chapter of the Bell Church in Barangay Macasandig.
=== Languages ===
Cebuano is the primarily spoken language in the city. English is mainly used for business and in the academe. Maranao is widely spoken by the city's Muslim community
column2: majority of whom are ethnic Maranaos. Subanen
column3: Bukid
column4: Higaonon
column6: and Waray are also spoken to varying degrees by their respective communities within the city.

column1: == Economy ==
Cagayan de Oro is the regional center and logistics and business hub of Northern Mindanao. The city's economy is largely based on industry
column3: trade
column4: service and tourism. Investment in Cagayan de Oro City for the first six months of 2012 reached 7.4 billion pesos outpacing the local government's expectation of to nearly 100 percent. Investments in the city are dominated by malls
column5: high-rise hotels and condominiums and convention centers. The net income for 2012 pegged at 2
column8: 807.89 billion pesos.

column1: It noted the United Nations cited  Cagayan de Oro City  in 2014 as “emerging city of tomorrow
column2: ” owing to its strong fundamentals that help strengthen its position as an emerging business leader in Mindanao.

column1: FWD Life Philippines President and CEO Peter Grimes said that Cagayan de Oro City is emerging as the economic and financial center of Mindanao due to the city's conducive peace and order condition
column3: its readily available and well-trained human resource
column4: government efficiency and appropriate infrastructure.Cagayan de Oro is home of the multi-billion peso fuel import facility of Pilipinas Shell Petroleum Corporation
column5: dubbed as the North Mindanao Import Facility (NMIF).In 2018
column6: during the 6th Regional Competitiveness Summit organized by the Department of Trade and Industry
column7: Cagayan de Oro City was named as the country's “Top 5 Most Competitive City” in the highly urbanized cities category
column8: notching five ranks higher as compared to its overall ranking last year outranking the country's top financial center

== Culture and arts ==

There are several notable events in the city. Each barangay or barrio has its own feast locally known as Fiesta (or festivals) honoring their patron saints after achieving recognition in their own rights.
The Higalaay Festival (formerly the Kagay-an Festival
column2: then the Higalaay Kagay-an Festival) is a week-long celebration in honor of Cagayan de Oro's patron saint St. Augustine held every August.

column1: Highlights of the Higalaay Festival are the Kahimunan Trade Fair
column2: which features the native products of the city and province
column3: particularly agricultural
column4: Miss Cagayan de Oro
column5: Folkloric Street Dancing Competition featuring colorful attires and cultural dances of the Higaonon tribes
column6: Higalas Parade of Cagayan de Oro Icons and Floats
column8: PE Rhythmic Dance Competition
column10: a culinary show and exhibit that started in 1996 by Kagay-anons hoteliers and restaurants. It has since evolved over the years and now hosts a culinary competition among students and professionals from all over Mindanao. The competition is divided into students and professionals where hotel and restaurant management schools and professional chefs compete against each other in their respective categories. There are also cultural shows
column11: competitions and celebrity concerts. In more recent years
column12: some of these competitions have been replaced with new ones
column13: such as the Folkloric Street Dancing Competition
column14: which was replaced by the Cagayan de Oro Carnival Parade in 2014.The annual religious tradition of the Feast of the Black Nazarene in Cagayan de Oro City is held every January 9 by having a procession called “Traslacion” in which hundreds of thousands of devotees participate. Cagayan de Oro is one of only three sites in the country to have this ‘Traslacion’.

column1: Himugso
column3: is a week-long celebration of Cagayan de Oro's Charter Day and Philippine Independence Day. Cagayan de Oro's cityhood was established on June 15
column4: 1950. Independence Day is the national commemoration of the Philippine Declaration of Independence from Spain on June 12
column5: 1898. Both Charter Day and Independence day are non-working holidays and a roster of special activities is lined up annually to mark the dual special occasion.

column1: === Cuisine ===
Cagayan de Oro food cultures include a variety of world cuisines influenced by the city's immigrant history. Western and Austronesian immigrants have made the city famous for pastel bread
column2: chicharrón and Hamon de Cagayan. Some mobile food vendors licensed by the city sell street food like kwek-kwek
column3: fish balls
column4: tempura and proven and grilled meat.

column1: Cagayan de Oro has local
column3: and foreign owned restaurants (Chinese and Korean cuisines)
column4: eateries
column8: and coffee shops that sprout all over the city.

column5: a sports and entertainment complex that also hosts concerts. The Pelaez Memorial Sports Center serves as the home complex of Misamis Oriental sports teams.

column1: Cagayan de Oro's new indoor sport is go-karting. The Speed Master Go Kart Race Track at SM City Carpark Building was the first race track in the city and in Mindanao. F1 Go Karts will be the second facility of its kind in the city and the first to use electric cars.
== Infrastructure ==
=== Transportation ===
As the gateway to Northern Mindanao and the rest of Mindanao
column2: Cagayan de Oro is accessible via land
column3: air and water transportation.  Main public transportation systems within the City are metered taxis
column4: jeepneys with fixed routes
column5: and motorelas within Poblacion. There are also a couple of river taxis that ply down to the Cagayan de Oro River for both locals and tourists.

column1: The Port of Cagayan de Oro in Macabalan is located near the estuary of the Cagayan de Oro River. It has an anchorage depth of 18 meters and is around 400 meters from the shoreline. It has four large gantry cranes and the biggest international and domestic seaport in Mindanao. It handled 1.399 million metric tons of cargoes during the first quarter of 2016 to rank 3rd in the country after Manila's North Harbor with 5.557 million metric tons and MICT with 3.746 million metric tons. The Port of Cagayan de Oro increased its volume of cargoes by 9.7% from 2015. This is according to data from the Philippine Ports Authority (PPA).
The Port of Cagayan de Oro (Macabalan Port) serves regular trips to and from cities of Metro Manila
column3: Tagbilaran
column4: Bacolod

column1: General Milling and Del Monte Philippines also operate their own port facilities within Cagayan de Oro. The $85 million Mindanao International Container Port located in nearby town Tagoloan 17 kilometers from Cagayan de Oro serves the PHIVIDEC Industrial Estate. This city's sub-port connects Mindanao to the ports of major cities in Visayas
column3: Metro Manila and the rest of the world.

column1: ==== Bus terminals ====
There are two bus terminals in the City: The Eastbound Integrated Bus Terminal also known as Market City and The Westbound Integrate Bus and Jeepney Termminal.

The Eastbound integrated Bus Terminal (Agora) also known as Market City offers regular landtrips to and from eastern municipalities of Misamis Oriental or eastern part of Mindanao including Balingoan and Gingoog
column3: Nasipit
column4: Butuan (change buses travel to Surigao City)
column5: Bukidnon including Central or Southern portion of Mindanao such as Malaybalay and Valencia
column8: Tacurong and General Santos.

column1: The Westbound Integrated Bus and Jeepney Terminal also has regular land trips to and from western municipalities of Misamis Oriental or Western part of Mindanao including El Salvador and Laguindingan
column3: Marawi
column4: Tangub
column8: and the rest of Zamboanga Peninsula including Pagadian and Zamboanga City.

column1: === Public utilities ===
Water services are provided by the Cagayan de Oro Water District (COWD)
column2: the first water district established in the entire Philippines. The Bulk Water Supply
column3: a supply agreement between COWD and the contractor
column4: has a total production capacity of 198
column6: and comes from treated water from Cagayan de Oro river
column7: the main water source of the city.

column1: Electricity in the city is provided mainly by Cagayan Electric Power and Light Company (CEPALCO) and partly by Misamis Oriental 1st Rural Electric Service Cooperative (MORESCO-1). Cagayan Electric Power and Light Company (CEPALCO). CEPALCO
column3: covers almost all of Cagayan de Oro and the Municipalities of Tagoloan
column4: Villanueva and Jasaan
column5: all in the Province of Misamis Oriental
column7: 000-hectare PHIVIDEC Industrial Estate and caters to more than 100
column8: 000 consumers. The company's distribution system network includes 138
column14: 800 volt systems. CEPALCO's power supply is mainly coming from embedded power generators
column15: namely: 165MW-Coal Power Plant of Minergy Power Corporation in Balingasag
column16: 46MW-Diesel Power Plants of Minergy in Tablon
column17: 8MW-Cabulig Hydro Electric Power Plant in Claveria
column20: 12.5MW Kirahon Solar Power Plant in Villanueva. CEPALCO is also operating the Developing World's first and largest (at the time of its inauguration in 2004) on-grid solar photovoltaic power plant. The 1-megawatt polycrystalline silicon-based photovoltaic (PV) plant in Barangay Indahag of this city is connected with the distribution network of CEPALCO. It is the biggest solar power plant connected to the power grid in Southeast Asia. Misamis Oriental -1 Rural Electric Service Cooperative (MORESCO-1) whose office is located in Laguindingan covers remote parts of Cagayan de Oro. These are barangays Canitoan

column1: === Law and order ===
Cagayan de Oro is the regional base of Philippine Air Force
column3: and Philippine National Police in Northern Mindanao.

column1: The Philippine Air Force is using Lumbia Airport as its air base which is currently operating a service equipment of OV-10 Bronco aircraft as well as UH-1 Huey and MD-520MG Defender helicopters. This will be a future home of the 15th Air Strike Wing that will be moving out from Sangley Point in Cavite

The Philippine Army operates the largest military camp in Mindanao located in Barangay Patag with an area of 129 hectares. It is home to the 4th infantry division of the Philippine Army. Camp Evangelista's external jurisdiction covers the Northern Mindanao and Caraga regions. Minor military camps are also located in barangay Lumbia and upper Puerto.
The Philippine National Police also operates its Regional Headquarters at Camp Alagar in Barangay Lapasan. Camp Alagar has jurisdiction over the entire Northern Mindanao
column3: Camiguin
column4: Lanao del Norte
column5: Misamis Occidental and Misamis Oriental including its major cities; Cagayan de Oro and Iligan.Recently
column7: AFP and spearheaded by LGU of Cagayan de Oro formed a new integrated security force of the city known as Task Force Oro.

column1: The local government of Cagayan de Oro upgraded its emergency services as it launched on Monday
column4: dialing the 911 number will immediately link the call to CDRRMC. The city patterned its improved emergency response program after Davao City's Central 911 emergency call. CDO's 911 will utilize Computer-Aided Emergency response.

column1: Cagayan de Oro is one of the three locations in the country where the Judiciary's Court of Appeals is holding office. The Court of Appeals of the Philippines is the Philippines' second-highest judicial court. Cagayan de Oro's Court of Appeals has 3 divisions covering all of Mindanao.
=== Medical facilities ===
Cagayan de Oro has a hospital bed-to-population ratio of 1:474 as of 2003. The Justiniano R. Borja General Hospital (a.k.a. City Hospital)
column2: the Camp Evangelista Station Hospital (Phil. Army)
column3: and Northern Mindanao Medical Center (formerly Provincial Hospital) are the three government-run hospitals.

column1: Capitol University Medical City
column3: Polymedic Medical Plaza
column4: Maria Reyna–Xavier University Hospital
column8: Puerto Community Hospital
column9: and Maternity-Children's Hospital and Puericulture Center (formerly Oro Doctor's Hospital) are privately owned.

column1: A special medical facility for drug-abuse treatment and rehabilitation is the Department of Health-Treatment and Rehabilitation Center-Cagayan de Oro located at Upper Puerto
Many of these government-owned and privately owned hospital facilities have undergone expansion
== Education ==
The City has four major private universities/colleges: Capitol University
column3: Lourdes College Cagayan de Oro City
column4: and Xavier University – Ateneo de Cagayan. The University of Science and Technology of Southern Philippines is the only state university in the city. Other higher education institutions include Southern Philippines College
column7: St. Mary's Academy of Carmen run by the RVM Sisters
column8: Informatics Institute and STI College - Cagayan de Oro with Senior High School programs. There are also a number of foreign schools in the city with study programs.

column1: Notable public and private elementary and high schools include Cagayan de Oro National High School
column3: Misamis Oriental General Comprehensive High School
column4: Gusa Regional Science High School - X
column8: The Abba's Orchard Montessori School
column13: and Montessori de Oro. There are also schools in Cagayan de Oro that use the Accelerated Christian Education system. Two of these schools include Cavite Bible Baptist Academy-CDO branch
column14: and Shekinah Glory Christian Academy. There are two Chinese schools in the city: Kong Hua School (Roman Catholic) and Oro Christian Grace School (an Evangelical Christian school). There are two international schools run by Koreans
column15: namely: Nanuri International School and Immanuel Mission International School.

column1: == Media ==
Notable media publications in the city are the Mindanao Gold Star Daily
column3: and Super Balita. Ang Katarungan is the city's major English-Cebuano language paper published since 1926. Brigada Newspaper Cagayan de Oro is the most popular newspaper company in the city. Mindanao Business Daily and BusinessWeek Mindanao are two business publications of BusinessWeek Mindanao Group of Publications.

column3: GMA Northern Mindanao contributed to local flagship news program One Mindanao (simulcast over GMA Davao) that broadcast in the whole Mindanao.

column1: == Local government ==
Elected and appointed public officials have governed Cagayan de Oro since June 15
column3: with a strong mayor-council government. The city political government is composed of the mayor
column4: vice mayor
column7: one Sangguniang Kabataan (SK) Federation representative and an Association of Barangay Captains (ABC) representative. Each official is elected publicly to a three-year terms.

=== Barangay and legislative districts ===
Cagayan de Oro is politically subdivided into 80 barangays. These are grouped into two congressional districts
column2: 24 barangays in the 1st district (West) and 56 barangays in the 2nd district (East)
column3: with the Cagayan de Oro River as the natural boundary. The city has a 57 urbanized barangays and 23 rural barangays all in all.
